# Order of the Highest Privilege (Ottoman Empire)

Ottoman Empire
| awarded_for = In the Ottoman Empire, it was given to reward its subjects and allies.
| status = Not provided.
| date = 1879
| higher = Order of Distinction
| lower = Order of Merit (tr)
| same = None
| native_name = Nişan-ı Âli İmtiyaz
| image = Hoge Orde van de Eer Ottomaanse Rijk 2.jpg
| image_size = 100
}}
The Order of High Privilege (Ottoman Turkish: Nişan-ı Âli İmtiyaz) was a badge of honour created in 1879 during the reign of Sultan Abdülhamid II to reward subjects and allies of the Ottoman Empire.
Description
The insignia of the Order bore the Sultan's Tughra on a badge decorated with gold and diamonds. The badge was attached to a red-green moiré ribbon with a suspension device containing the Ottoman national emblem the Star and crescent.
Recipients
In 1885, it was awarded to King Christian IX of Denmark.
